instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S5
threads.message:
My reference: REF1144

Board History: Some liquid damage, would not power on at all.
Replaced: <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7689</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7651</CAPACITOR>.
USB meter goes to 20v.
When I first plug in the charger, I see it jumps up to about 3v on <CAPACITOR>C7651</CAPACITOR> during the first few seconds of being plugged in, but it drops off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S5
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?

Check diode mode to ground on all power rails and compare with good board.
Also check basic voltages on <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>; pins 23, 22, 12, 13, 29, 21.
Be sure all resistors and traces from feedback networks are good.

Any pulse at L7690?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S5
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 101647, member: 682"]
Any pulse at L7690?
[/QUOTE]
Nothing at L7690. I do not have a known good board.

All my measurements I have been providing has been with the board out on the desk.

<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> Pins:
23: 13.04v
22: 3.29v
12: 0v
13: 0v
29: 0v
21: 0v

All power rails before leading up to S5 seem to be present. There is damage in the backlight areas but this is for S0, would the backlight compomnents affect this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S5
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL]

No pulse at all at pin 12?
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> comes high (stable)?

Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10) output voltages; its <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S5
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 101657, member: 682"]
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
[/QUOTE]
Yes, 3.4v and stable.

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, I am not confident which <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> voltages I am supposed to check:
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SYSPWROK</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_ALLSYSPGD</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_INT_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_P1V8</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>: 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>: 3.089v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_VCCST_PGD</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL>: 13.04v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVCCPCH</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_PGB</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_PGD</SIGNAL>: 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No S5
threads.message:
I specified <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10) section!
You've missed all of them...
